titleproper.value: Guide to the David Karsner Papers on the Bill Haywood Espionage Trial <num>TAM 430</num>

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-06-01T20:24:16</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

unittitle.value: David Karsner Papers on the Bill Haywood Espionage Trial

abstract.value: David Karsner (1889-1941) was a socialist activist, author and newspaperman who served for some years as an editor of the Socialist Party's newspaper, <emph render="italic">The New York Call</emph>.  The collection contains correspondence, transcripts and clippings relating primarily to Karsner's coverage of the 1918 trial, <emph render="italic">The United States of America v. William D. Haywood, et al.</emph>, held in the District Court of the United States, Northern District of Illinois, Eastern Division in Chicago.

p.value: Materials found in collection; provenance is unknown. The accession number associated with this collectionis 1950.241.

The collection contains clippings, correspondence and transcripts relating primarily to Karsner's coverage of the 1918 trial,<emph render="italic">The United States of America v. William D. Haywood, et al.</emph>  Notable items include correspondence from William D. "Big Bill" Haywood written while incarcerated in Leavenworth, Kansas, and as a fugitive in the Soviet Union; an original sketch made by Haywood in the courtroom; and Karsner's dispatch to <emph render="italic">The New York Call</emph> describing the emotional courtroom meeting of Haywood and Eugene V. Debs.  Correspondents include Roger N. Baldwin of the National Civil Liberties Bureau and A.S. Embree and K.B. McDonald of the General Defense Committee of the Industrial Workers of the World (I.W.W.).  Trial transcripts document statements made by defendants prior to sentencing, and clippings relate mostly to the trial and Haywood's subsequent escape to Moscow.  The two separated photographs are of George V. Vanderveer, General Counsel for the I.W.W., and Frank K. Nebeker, Chief Prosecutor.
